item.title: Seaside poor health overlooked, warns Whitty
item.description: Bad housing and deprivation are a toxic mix for health, says England's chief medical officer.

item.title: Non-surgical beauty treatment industry like Wild West - MPs
item.description: "Complete absence" of regulation of treatments such as botox-style injections and fillers condemned by MPs.

item.title: Covid-19: Crucial for pinged people to self-isolate - No 10
item.description: Downing Street tries to clear up confusion after a minister says people can make an "informed decision".

item.title: Covid: Hundreds of thousands of under-18s to get vaccine
item.description: The vaccines minister says children at high risk from Covid will be offered the jab.

item.title: Covid: Mask wearing return for Jersey as cases rise
item.description: Mask wearing will be mandatory in public indoor settings again after a rise in Jersey Covid cases.

item.title: Covid: Isolation rules loosened for critical workers
item.description: People performing "critical" tasks including air traffic controllers will still be able to work under new rules.

item.title: Covid: Lifting all restrictions at once is reckless, says Sir Keir Starmer
item.description: Boris Johnson has urged caution as most legal rules on social contact are lifted in England.

item.title: Covid: Global healthcare workers missing out on jabs
item.description: Campaigners say millions have not had even one vaccine dose, raising concerns for their communities.

item.title: 19 July: England Covid restrictions ease as PM urges caution
item.description: There is no limit on how many people can meet, nightclubs can reopen and large events can resume.

item.title: Covid: Double-jabbed NHS staff could avoid isolation if service under pressure
item.description: Fully-vaccinated health workers in England could skip quarantine if services come under pressure.

item.title: Covid: UK faces a difficult summer, says leading scientist
item.description: Prof Neil Ferguson says there could be as many as 200,000 cases a day as restrictions ease.

item.title: Long Covid funding to unearth new treatments
item.description: Researchers from across the UK will investigate everything from brain fog to ongoing breathlessness.

item.title: Covid: What happens when people no longer have to wear masks?
item.description: Face coverings became optional in many settings in England on Monday - what's the evidence for them?

item.title: Heatwaves: What do they do to the body and who is at risk?
item.description: What impact do high temperatures have on our bodies?

item.title: Covid-19 rules: How six countries fared after easing Covid rules
item.description: As England approaches an end to social contact laws, how have other countries managed?

item.title: NHS Covid app: Should it stay or should it go?
item.description: There is a clash over the future of the NHS tracing app, as many delete it - or ignore its alerts.

item.title: Dying too young: Maps show little has changed in 170 years
item.description: Why do areas with high Covid death rates match places with the worst health in Victorian times?

item.title: Covid-19: 'For us it's not freedom day, is it?'
item.description: Their medical conditions mean they are considered vulnerable to Covid. How are they feeling now?

item.title: 'Holiday food poisoning left me paralysed'
item.description: Malcolm Brown developed a rare autoimmune disease after suffering food poisoning while on a self-catering trip.

item.title: Marr on catching Covid after being double vaccinated
item.description: The BBC's Andrew Marr fell ill with Covid-19, despite being vaccinated twice.

item.title: Your questions about vaccines and periods answered
item.description: Find out what experts believe the short and long term effects of a covid jab will be on your period.

item.title: Long Covid: 'I've blood clots, a braced leg and damaged heart... but I'm home'
item.description: For three months, Bill Wilson lived a nightmare, trapped behind a plastic facemask fighting Covid.

item.title: Which children are being vaccinated and why?
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of children at higher risk from coronavirus infection will be offered a Covid vaccine in the UK.

item.title: Why you shouldn't get a second Covid jab too early
item.description: A government scientific advisor tells Newsbeat why four weeks is too soon between Covid jabs.

item.title: Beta coronavirus variant: What is the risk?
item.description: There are fears that this version of coronavirus, first identified in South Africa, is

item.title: Covid rules: How can the clinically vulnerable stay safe?
item.description: As social-distancing and other Covid rules end in England, how can people who were shielding stay safe?

item.title: What are the rules and guidance for face masks and coverings from 19 July?
item.description: Masks are no longer compulsory in England, but remain necessary in Scotland and Wales.

item.title: How many cases in your area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: What do over-18s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: All over-18s can now get the Covid jab, but Boris Johnson has criticised the take-up among young people.

item.title: What are the India, Brazil, South Africa and UK variants?
item.description: UK coronavirus cases are rising due to a variant first identified in India that spreads more easily.

item.title: Covid rules from 19 July: What has changed?
item.description: Major changes to lockdown rules have taken effect in England and Scotland, but some restrictions remain.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Experts think a limited group of children should be offered Covid jabs ahead of winter.

item.title: How do we know Covid vaccines are safe?
item.description: Busting myths and explaining the facts around vaccines.

item.title: Coronavirus: What it does to the body
item.description: What is it like to have the coronavirus, how will it affect you and how is it treated?

item.title: Support bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: Some people across the UK have been able to form "support bubbles" or "extended households".

item.title: How to get a Covid test
item.description: Everyone in England and Scotland is being encouraged to take rapid coronavirus tests regularly.

item.title: All you need to know on the coronavirus
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus: Intensive care and other key terms explained
item.description: Use our tool to check the meaning of key words and phrases associated with the Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the risk to men over 50?
item.description: While most people will have mild symptoms and recover quickly, some are more prone to getting sick.

item.title: Coronavirus: Do face masks actually work?
item.description: With face masks in high demand, we look at whether they really can protect people from the virus.

item.title: Covid: Can children have the Covid vaccine in the UK?
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of under-18s will now be offered the jab in the UK - but not all. Here's why.

item.title: Shielders 'feeling abandoned' as coronavirus restrictions lifted
item.description: Three people who were told to shield during lockdown share their concerns as rules are eased in England.

item.title: Nadhim Zahawi: At-risk children aged 12-17 to be offered vaccine
item.description: The vaccines minister says children with health conditions will be offered the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine

item.title: Covid patients urge public to 'be careful' as restrictions ease
item.description: As most coronavrirus restrictions in England are lifted, Covid patients urge the public to take care.

item.title: Covid vaccine: How are young people responding to the jab?
item.description: The Covid vaccine is now being offered to all over 18s. So what has uptake been like for young people?
